p.span: EMBEDDING TANGLES IN LINKS
DANIEL RUBERMAN
Department of Mathematics
MS 050
Brandeis University
Waltham, MA 02254
ABSTRACT
Extending and reproving a recent result of D.Â Krebes, we give obstructions to the embedding of a tangle in a link.
Keywords: Tangle, link, determinant, branched covering

div.p: A recent paperÂ [2] of David Krebes poses the following interesting question: given a tangle ğ’¯ğ’¯caligraphic-T{\cal T}, and a link â„’â„’caligraphic-L{\cal L}, when can ğ’¯ğ’¯caligraphic-T{\cal T}Â sit inside â„’â„’caligraphic-L{\cal L}? A tangle is a 11NUMBER:11-manifold with 4 boundary components, properly embedded in a 3-ball; this is somewhat more general than the usual definition. An embedding of ğ’¯ğ’¯caligraphic-T{\cal T}Â in â„’â„’caligraphic-L{\cal L}Â is determined by a ball in S3superscriptğ‘†3italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{3}, whose intersection with â„’â„’caligraphic-L{\cal L}Â is the given tangle; we will indicate an embedding by ğ’¯â†ªâ„’â†ªğ’¯â„’caligraphic-T ARROW:hookrightarrow caligraphic-L{{\cal T}}\hookrightarrow{{\cal L}}. Krebes gives the following simple criterion for when ğ’¯ğ’¯caligraphic-T{{\cal T}} embeds in â„’â„’caligraphic-L{\cal L}. Complete the tangle to a link in either of the two obvious ways, giving rise to the numerator nâ¢(ğ’¯)ğ‘›ğ’¯italic-n OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:)n({{\cal T}}) and denominator dâ¢(ğ’¯)ğ‘‘ğ’¯italic-d OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:)d({{\cal T}}). For any oriented link â„’â„’caligraphic-L{{\cal L}}, its determinant detâ¡(â„’)â„’LIMITOP:determinant OPEN:( caligraphic-L CLOSE:)\det({{\cal L}}) is defined to be detâ¡(V+Vâ€²)ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‰â€²LIMITOP:determinant OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:plus italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\det(V+V^{\prime}), where Vğ‘‰italic-VV is a Seifert matrix for â„’â„’caligraphic-L{{\cal L}}. div.p: The proof of TheoremÂ 1 given inÂ [2] is essentially combinatorial, and uses an interpretation of the determinant in terms of link diagrams and the Kauffman bracket. On the other hand, the determinant has a homological interpretation; it is essentially the order of the homology of the 22NUMBER:22-fold branched cover S3superscriptğ‘†3italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{3}, branched along the link. In this paper, we will prove a simple fact about the homology of certain 33NUMBER:33-manifolds, which readily implies TheoremÂ 1. In essence, we replace the divisibility condition above with the conclusion that the homology of the 22NUMBER:22-fold branched cover of the link must contain a subgroup of a certain size. Our approach has the advantage that it gives some stronger results on the embedding problem, which do not seem approachable via the combinatorial route. A slightly different argument yields a similar conclusion about other branched coverings as well. Some examples, and further remarks on embeddings, are given in the final section.

div.p: Second, the proof gives a somewhat stronger condition, involving the homology groups themselves, rather than their orders. We give the statement in terms of the homology of 33NUMBER:33-manifolds, with the understanding that passing to the 2-fold cover of a link gives rise to a restriction on embeddings of tangles in links.

div.p: Most of the results so far have concerned only the torsion part of the homology, but there are some things which can be said about the torsion-free part of the homology. One simple result is the following.

Hence both of these inject into the homology of Nğ‘italic-NN.

p.span: It is not hard to give examples where the homological approach gives more information than can be deduced from the determinants alone. The simplest I can think of is the following. Let Tnormal-Tcaligraphic-T{{\cal T}} be the tangle

section.h2: 4 An obstruction to embedding in a trivial link

div.p: An obstruction to embedding tangles in the trivial link, of a somewhat different sort, may be derived from the invariants Inâ¢(ğ’¯)superscriptğ¼ğ‘›ğ’¯italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-T CLOSE:)I^{n}({{\cal T}}) defined inÂ [4]. div.p: Proof: Consider first a 22NUMBER:22-string tangle ğ’¦ğ’¦caligraphic-K{\cal K} with no loops, and the 4-punctured sphere Î£Î£Sigma\Sigma in the boundary of its exterior. Then Î£Î£Sigma\Sigma is compressible if and only if ğ’¦ğ’¦caligraphic-K{\cal K} is split, where ğ’¦ğ’¦caligraphic-K{\cal K} is split if the ball can be split into two sub-balls by a properly embedded disk with the two strings of ğ’¦ğ’¦caligraphic-K{\cal K} lying in different sub-balls. This follows directly from the loop theorem and Dehnâ€™s lemma. The structure of a split tangle is very simple: it is a trivial tangle possibly with knots tied in each string. The tangle is trivial if and only if there are no knots. In particular, a split tangle has In=0superscriptğ¼ğ‘›0italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0I^{n}=0 for all nğ‘›italic-nn, because it has a completion which is a split link, which in turn has all of its Î²n=0superscriptğ›½ğ‘›0italic-beta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\beta^{n}=0.

The tangles cited inÂ [4] give rise to examples of tangles which cannot be embedded in a trivial link.

We close with a few remarks on some of the questions raised at the end ofÂ [2]. One question concerned the existence of a family of completions of any tangle with 2â¢t2ğ‘¡NUMBER:2 italic-t2t strands, which would play the role of the numerator and denominator of a 22NUMBER:22-string tangle. Following the proof of TheoremsÂ 2 andÂ 3 we see how to construct such a family. Note that the 22NUMBER:22-fold branched cover of a trivial 2â¢t2ğ‘¡NUMBER:2 italic-t2t-tangle is a handlebody of genus 2â¢t-12ğ‘¡1NUMBER:2 italic-t ADDOP:minus NUMBER:12t-1. By twisting the strings around, one can vary the attaching of this complementary handlebody so as to kill of the homology of âˆ‚â¡Mğ‘€OPERATOR:partial-differential italic-M\partial M in various fillings. The gcdOPFUNCTION:gcd\gcd of the orders of the homology of all these fillings then would have to divide the determinant of any link in which the tangle was embedded.

Another generalization of a tangle pointed out in Â§14 ofÂ [2] is an embedded arc (or more generally a 11NUMBER:11-manifold) in a more complicated submanifold of S3superscriptğ‘†3italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{3}, such as a solid torus. In particular, Krebes asks whether a particular arc ğ’œğ’œcaligraphic-A{\cal A} in a S1Ã—D2superscriptğ‘†1superscriptğ·2italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{1}\times D^{2} (Figure 17 ofÂ [2]) can sit inside an unknot. Our approach, especially CorollaryÂ 2 gives (in principle) an obstruction, if there were torsion in the homology of some cover of S1Ã—D2superscriptğ‘†1superscriptğ·2italic-S POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:times italic-D POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endS^{1}\times D^{2} branched along ğ’œğ’œcaligraphic-A{\cal A}. Unfortunately, it seems that the homology of all of the cylic covers of the solid torus, branched along this arc, is torsion-free. Hence we cannot apply TheoremÂ 3 to deduce anything about embeddings of this pair in a link. Likewise, it does not seem possible to use TheoremÂ 4, because the rational homology of each of the cyclic branched covers is the same as for a trivial arc.
